Editing portraits can be a delicate process! I'm happy to help you with that.

**Enhancing Skin Tones:**

1. **Use the right color grading tools**: Adjust the white balance, exposure, and contrast to create a natural-looking skin tone. You can use the "Skin Tone" or "Portrait" presets in your editing software as a starting point.
2. **Warm up or cool down**: Adjust the temperature of the image to suit your subject's skin tone. Warm tones (yellow/orange) can add a healthy glow, while cool tones (blue/purple) can help reduce redness.
3. **Local adjustments**: Use the "Brush" or "Spot Healing" tool to make local adjustments to specific areas of the skin, such as brightening up dark circles or reducing redness around the nose and mouth.
4. **Soften skin texture**: Use the "Clarity" or "Texture" slider to soften skin texture and reduce the appearance of pores. Be cautious not to overdo it, as it can look unnatural.

**Removing Blemishes:**

1. **Spot Healing Brush**: Use the "Spot Healing Brush" tool to remove small blemishes, such as pimples or freckles. This tool is usually available in most editing software, including Adobe Lightroom and Photoshop.
2. **Clone Stamp**: For larger blemishes, use the "Clone Stamp" tool to copy and paste healthy skin texture over the affected area.
3. **Frequency Separation**: This technique involves separating the image into two layers: one for texture and one for tone. This allows you to edit the tone layer to remove blemishes without affecting the texture. You can find tutorials online for frequency separation in your preferred editing software.

**Avoiding Over-Editing:**

1. **Less is more**: Remember, the goal is to enhance, not to completely remove, blemishes. Over-editing can lead to an unnatural, plastic look.
2. **Use subtle adjustments**: Make subtle adjustments and check your work frequently to avoid over-processing.
3. **Work on a copy**: Always work on a copy of the original image, so you can easily revert to the original if needed.
4. **Check your work**: Zoom in and out of the image to ensure your edits look natural and not overdone.

**Software Recommendations:**

1. **Adobe Lightroom**: An excellent choice for portrait editing, with powerful tools for adjusting skin tones and removing blemishes.
2. **Adobe Photoshop**: Offers advanced tools, including the "Spot Healing Brush" and "Clone Stamp," for more intricate editing.
3. **Skylum Luminar**: A user-friendly, all-in-one editing software with AI-powered tools for portrait editing.
4. **Capture One**: A professional-grade editing software with advanced tools for portrait editing and skin tone adjustments.

Remember, the key to natural-looking edits is to make subtle adjustments and avoid over-processing. Practice makes perfect, so experiment with different techniques and software to find what works best for you!
